com.ihordev.core.repositories

Class QueryTemplateUtils

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.ihordev.core.repositories.QueryTemplateUtils

  • public final class QueryTemplateUtils
extends Object

    A class with utility methods that allows to automatically create some JPQL clauses and JPQL query template variables for entities.

    • Method Summary

    • Method Detail

      • createSelectClause

        public static <T> String createSelectClause(Class<T> queryResultClass,
                                            List<EntityVariable> queryEntityVariables)

        Creates SELECT clause that corresponds to queryResultClass properties. Created clause consists of columns with aliases equal to queryResultClass properties names. If some properties of class are dynamically calculated values then getters for this properties must have ColumnExpression annotation specified.

        It takes properties from queryResultClass and for each property tries to find EntityVariable whose entity originally owns this property. When it is found it generates "entityAlias.property AS property", where entityAlias is received by calling entityVariable.getAsAliasValue() method.

        If property from queryResultClass is annotated with ColumnExpression annotation, then it generates "columnExpression AS property", where columnExpression is received from ColumnExpression annotation value.

        When two EntityVariable instances have same properties, preference will be given to first found. So, to choose from which EntityVariable instance property with equal name must be taken one can use insertion order in queryEntityVariables. If two EntityVariable instances have multiple properties with same names and for each such property EntityVariable instance must be chosen in different preference than such complex SELECT clause must be written manually.

        Note: properties are always sorted in alphabetic order.

        Example usage:

        Let's say queryResultClass is a Spring Data JPA projection: 

        
 public interface SomeProjection {

     String getFieldOne();

     String getFieldTwo();

     @ColumnExpression(value = "expression")
     String getFieldThree();
 }
        and there are also two entities: 
        
 @Entity
 public class SomeEntityOne {
     private Object fieldOne;
     public Object getFieldOne() {
         return fieldOne;
     }
 }
 @Entity
 public class SomeEntityTwo {
     private Object fieldTwo;
     public Object getFieldTwo() {
         return fieldTwo;
     }
 }
        then: 
        
 List<EntityVariable> queryEntityVariables = new ArrayList<>();
 queryEntityVariables.add(new EntityVariable(SomeEntityOne.class, "entityOne"));
 queryEntityVariables.add(new EntityVariable(SomeEntityTwo.class, "entityTwo"));

 String createdSelectClause = createSelectClause(SomeProjection.class,
          queryEntityVariables);
        Value of createdSelectClause would be: "someEntityOne.fieldOne AS fieldOne, expression AS fieldThree, someEntityOne.fieldTwo AS fieldTwo"
        Type Parameters:
        T - the query result class type parameter
        Parameters:
        queryResultClass - the class that is used as return type of query
        queryEntityVariables - the list that contains EntityVariable instances of query
        Returns:
        the created SELECT clause string
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if property from queryResultClass cannot be found in any EntityVariable specified in queryEntityVariables

      • createGroupByClause

        public static <T> String createGroupByClause(Class<T> queryResultClass,
                                             List<EntityVariable> queryEntityVariables)

        Creates GROUP BY clause that corresponds to queryResultClass properties. If some properties of class are dynamically calculated values then getters for this properties must have ColumnExpression annotation specified. If column expression is an aggregate function (with ColumnExpression.isAggregate() set to true), then it is excluded from GROUP BY clause.

        It takes properties from queryResultClass and for each property tries to find EntityVariable whose entity originally owns this property and, when found, generates "entityAlias.property", where entityAlias is received by calling entityVariable.getAsAliasValue() method.

        If property from queryResultClass is annotated with ColumnExpression annotation, then it generates "columnExpression", where columnExpression is received from ColumnExpression annotation value.

        When two EntityVariable instances have same properties, preference will be given to first found. So, to choose from which EntityVariable instance property with equal name must be taken one can use insertion order in queryEntityVariables. If two EntityVariable instances have multiple properties with same names and for each such property EntityVariable instance must be chosen in different preference than such complex GROUP BY clause must be written manually.

        Note: properties are always sorted in alphabetic order.

        Example usage:

        Let's say queryResultClass is a Spring Data JPA projection: 

        
 public interface SomeProjection {

     String getFieldOne();

     String getFieldTwo();

     @ColumnExpression(value = "expression")
     String getFieldThree();

     @ColumnExpression(value = "aggregate", isAggregate = true)
     String getFieldFour();
 }
        and there are also two entities: 
        
 @Entity
 public class SomeEntityOne {
     private Object fieldOne;
     public Object getFieldOne() {
         return fieldOne;
     }
 }
 @Entity
 public class SomeEntityTwo {
     private Object fieldTwo;
     public Object getFieldTwo() {
         return fieldTwo;
     }
 }
        then: 
        
 List<EntityVariable> queryEntityVariables = new ArrayList<>();
 queryEntityVariables.add(new EntityVariable(SomeEntityOne.class, "entityOne"));
 queryEntityVariables.add(new EntityVariable(SomeEntityTwo.class, "entityTwo"));

 String createdSelectClause = createGroupByClause(SomeProjection.class,
          queryEntityVariables);
        Value of createdGroupByClause would be: "someEntityOne.fieldOne, expression, someEntityOne.fieldTwo"
        Type Parameters:
        T - the query result class type parameter
        Parameters:
        queryResultClass - the class that is used as return type of query
        queryEntityVariables - the list that contains EntityVariable instances of query
        Returns:
        the created GROUP BY clause string
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if property from queryResultClass cannot be found in any EntityVariable specified in queryEntityVariables

      • createOrderByClause

        public static String createOrderByClause(Sort sort,
                                         Class<?> queryResultClass)
        Creates ORDER BY clause. It takes Sort instance and for each Sort.Order instance in it generates "property direction" string, where property is received by calling Sort.Order.getProperty() method and direction is received by calling Sort.Order.getDirection() method.
        Parameters:
        queryResultClass - the class that is used as return type of query
        sort - the Sort instance containing ordering information
        Returns:
        the created ORDER BY clause string
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if property specified in Sort.Order cannot be found in queryResultClass

      • createTemplateVariablesForEntities

        public static Map<String,String> createTemplateVariablesForEntities(List<EntityVariable> queryEntityVariables)
        Creates a map that contains all template variables for each entity. It takes names of template variables by calling EntityVariable get methods which end on "Key" and their values by calling a corresponding get methods which end on "Value", and uses them as map entries values.
        Parameters:
        queryEntityVariables - the list that contains EntityVariable instances of query
        Returns:
        the map containing template variables of entity

      • createRowMapper

        public static <T> Function<Object[],T> createRowMapper(Class<T> queryResultClass)

        Creates row mapper function object that creates an instance of class specified in queryResultClass argument whose properties are populated with values taken from query result row.

        Note: properties are always sorted in alphabetic order. It is convenient to use this method in conjunction with createSelectClause(Class, List) method. If queryResultClass is a DTO class then it must have a no arg constructor.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the query result class type parameter
        Parameters:
        queryResultClass - the class that is used as return type of query
        Returns:
        the row mapper function object
